audio_caption: A woman speaks in an assertive tone about history books, hoping they will note Donald Trump put Kellyanne in a position to manage a US presidential campaign and notes she was "hiding in plain sight." She claims he consults with women, ensuring they are on equal footing with men, unlike some men in the White House. A brief sound effect is heard. She remarks that many of those men have tried to stop her.

A woman speaks, referencing her time working for President Obama and mentions the challenges he faced. She then contrasts this with President Trump's supporters, describing their deep commitment. Another woman responds, stating that most people see themselves as outsiders, which is how they perceive Donald Trump. She criticizes the Democratic nomination process for not selecting someone who represents forward-looking change. The clip concludes with a quiet sound.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker expressing a political viewpoint, suggesting that President Trump is "the incumbent outsider." Another female speaker questions the assumption that Joe Biden would be a difficult candidate to link to the radical left due to his long history, saying, "he's been around for 47 years." The first speaker interjects to say "his story isn't radical left, his story is American." A male speaker says "he also was working, he also." The first speaker continues with "is a brief and loss and a man who's done right by his family." She then adds "God bless him and we should all applaud that." The second speaker interjects that this is "a pretty good part of his story." The first speaker then adds "There is no reason that he should be doing the Bernie manifesto and listening to AOC on Green New Deal." A third female speaker speaks about "16, you know, what happened, what happened happened, we both know" and that "18, a lot of women left the Republicans, voted for Democrats in the midterm."

The clip begins with a conversation between two female speakers. One speaker questions the effectiveness of Joe Biden's support for certain individuals, remarking that they "didn't even ask him to campaign for them." The second speaker interjects, emphasizing that "Joe Biden is still doing better." The first speaker continues, suggesting that Joe Biden is "trying to fit into a party that left him a long time ago." The second speaker replies that, "Joe Biden is still doing better," highlighting a "gender gap." They then accuse someone of "running ads, trying to frighten women into supporting Trump."

The audio clip starts with a woman's voice expressing frustration with the term "women's issues", stating that she's never heard the phrase "men's issues" in her 30-year career. Another woman agrees. They acknowledge the idea that "men can think of everything but women", while women can only think of "a couple of things." The second woman also agrees with the first's premise that there's no such thing as a woman's issue, but states Biden is still doing better with women.

A woman is speaking in a confident and persuasive tone about the progress report. She mentions how women will know that the president "kept so many promises" and that "we love men who keep their promises." She continues, comparing what this president has done in 47 months to what Joe Biden didn't do in 47 years.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker pondering "the easiest way to contrast".
Another female responds in a conversational tone, asserting her belief in Donald Trump.
Another female speaker replies, stating her belief in America, emphasizing the need for a leader. 
Her tone then shifts as she critiques democrats, summarizing their perceived stance on the US leading in Covid deaths, a major economic downturn, and their reliance on a national tragedy for political gain.
She expresses disapproval, suggesting they are looking at the crisis as political opportunism.
A second female speaker joins in, arguing that Biden sees it as a vacuum of leadership. 
The first speaker then argues things turned around a few weeks ago when Trump tweeted about wearing masks.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker, in an informal tone, recalling a conversation where she predicted someone would receive 200,000 likes on a tweet, highlighting that people enjoy policy-related tweets with "directional advice". The speaker continues, mentioning advice given about coronavirus briefings, suggesting they be "succinct and technical". She then states that the President cancelled his live convention and rallies, stating, "What's good for thee is good for me", implying it was leadership. The speaker adds that the Democrats were sure of their success while setting up their convention and now feel, "holy crap this guy's coming back." Following this, the same speaker notes that there is "racial unrest" at the same time as the conventions.

The clip starts with a female speaker referring to a video of George Floyd, mentioning the president's reaction as "disgraceful." Another female speaker states, "I called it murder," and then discusses the video of Jacob Blake and unrest in different cities like Minneapolis, Portland, and Seattle. She mentions looting, vandalism, and loss of life, noting that people are walking around with firearms. Interspersed between the speech segments is ominous, suspenseful music with synthesized tones creating a somber mood. The clip concludes with a female speaker asking if the other "welcomes unrest" in her campaign and how she deals with it.

The clip begins with a female speaker expressing concern about the country being divided, stating "Of course it concerns me...we don't want our country divided". She discusses how beautiful cities and suburbs are being destroyed. Another female speaker interrupts to say, "But the public support". The first female speaker refutes that the protesters are peaceful, asking, "Do you think peaceful protesters killed two people in Kenosha overnight with firearms?" A low-pitched, melancholic, and eerie instrumental piece of music then plays. The clip concludes with another female speaker asking, "So, do you have any hope that this country can come together?"

The audio clip features two female speakers engaged in a lively conversation. One speaker expresses hope that President Trump did not try to win by "capturing a middle" or "bringing people to a side", while the other interjects, saying, "that's just not true." The first speaker continues, suggesting that a vast majority of Trump's support comes from white working-class Americans, to which the other speaker questions why they are being denounced and why they do not matter. The first speaker denies denouncing anyone. Another speaker talks about growing up in the same era and coming from a military family, adding that she doesnâ€™t know why there's "always this side being marked," not from her, but from many people, followed by, "the raised eyebrow, the furled." This is followed by the first speaker mentioning Trump's supporters.

The audio clip features a single female speaker expressing strong emotions, starting with the phrases "I always feel a fire in my belly and bile in my throat" while describing how she feels when people from her background are "mocked and ridiculed." She conveys a sense of frustration and disapproval with a serious tone. The speaker uses examples of people being looked down upon "because they go to church or they own a firearm," emphasizing the perceived injustice. There are no other speakers, discernible music, or background sounds to note.

The audio begins with a woman speaking in a conversational tone, stating she coined the term "hidden undercover Trump voter" and believes there are more such voters who will surprise people. She asserts many Trump supporters are afraid to express themselves, but they do so in the ballot box and predicts that the president will be ahead soon. This shifts to a dark, suspenseful musical piece featuring synth elements that evokes a sense of tension or mystery. Then, the clip ends with a sharp, metallic "clang" sound, possibly signaling danger or a sudden impact.
